items.body:
Hello,
I have been trying to install Anaconda for several days and I have always got the same message error: `"Failed to create menus"`. I have tried all the available solutions to this problem from changing the path variable to delete my Java environment, this came without any success. I finally decided to set up a new windows and I got the same error. with the same problem. I think it is a problem with python installation rather than conda.

items.title: 406 Client Error: Not Acceptable for URL ...
items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
3. When making a bug report, make sure you provide all required information. The easier it is for
   maintainers to reproduce, the faster it'll be fixed.
-->

## Description of the issue
Hi! 
I'm having a problem with building an executable from a python script. Running the python script works fine and building the pyinstaller .exe works fine. However, when running the .exe, I'm getting an **406 Client Error: Not Acceptable for url <...>**.

As the script usually works, there are no issues with the code, but rather with doing the API call from the executable. Do you have any idea of what might cause this? 

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```4.1.dev0```
* Version of Python:  3.7.6
* Platform: e.g GNU/Linux (distribution), Windows 10.0.17763 Build 17763
* Did you also try this on another platform? Not tried


* try the latest development version, using the following command:

```shell
pip install https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/archive/develop.zip
```

* follow *all* the instructions in our "If Things Go Wrong" Guide
  (https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/If-Things-Go-Wrong) and

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [x] start with clean installation
  * [x] use the latest development version
  * [x] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [x] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [x] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [x] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

```
from stix2 import TAXIICollectionSource
from taxii2client import Server, Collection

# Establish TAXII2 Collection instance for Enterprise ATT&CK collection
collection = Collection("https://cti-taxii.mitre.org/stix/collections/95ecc380-afe9-11e4-9b6c-751b66dd541e/")
```

### Stacktrace / full error message

```
  File "run.py", line 27, in <module>
  File "run.py", line 15, in run_program
  File "data.py", line 46, in __init__
  File "data.py", line 64, in fetch_mitre_data
  File "stix2\datastore\taxii.py", line 166, in __init__
stix2.datastore.DataSourceError: The underlying TAXII Collection resource defined in the supplied TAXII Collection object provided could not be reached. Recieved error: "406 Client Error: Not Acceptable for url: https://cti-taxii.mitre.org/stix/collections/95ecc380-afe9-11e4-9b6c-751b66dd541e/"
[22480] Failed to execute script run
```

Please also see <https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs>
for more about what would use to solve the issue.

items.title: Test the new pip dependency resolver works

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Feature request

items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The issue of the package not working on **`>Python 3.8`**
For all developers pip announced the way that installing packages will change before December 2020.
To prove it try installing another package with the latest version of pip and it will suggest that all packages should be tested with **`use-feature=2020-resolver`** for those developing packages

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The solution is for the developers to just test the command --use-feature=2020-resolver on their package before it becomes the default.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The method above is the only option I have that may work.

items.title: ImportError: No module named zope.interface
items.body:
In continue to #5080, after applying the fix I encounter a different issue when compiled with the `noarchive` flag everything is working but when running the `exe` I get this error:
```
(test_debug) C:\Users\arossert\test_debug>dist\app\app.exe
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\loader\rthooks\pyi_rth_twisted.py", line 25, in <module>
    from twisted.internet import default
  File "C:\Users\arossert\test_debug\Lib\site-packages\twisted/internet/default.py", line 56, in <module>
    install = _getInstallFunction(platform)
  File "C:\Users\arossert\test_debug\Lib\site-packages\twisted/internet/default.py", line 52, in _getInstallFunction
    from twisted.internet.selectreactor import install
  File "C:\Users\arossert\test_debug\Lib\site-packages\twisted/internet/selectreactor.py", line 15, in <module>
    from zope.interface import implementer
ImportError: No module named zope.interface
[10208] Failed to execute script pyi_rth_twisted
```

Again the `zope.interface`, I tried to add `--hidden-import=zope` or `--hidden-import=zope.interface`, nothing worked.
I also tried to add a `hook` with `datas = collect_data_files('zope')` but this ends up with `ImportError` while trying to apply the hook

The only thing that worked (after reading on this on-line) is adding `__init__.py` to the `zope` root dir in my `site-packages`.
When compiling without the `noarchive` flag everything works without any patching.

Is there any way to solve this without adding files?

PyInstaller: 3.6
Pyhton: 2.7.18
Platform: Windows10

items.title: Wxpython application with Matplotlib crashes when run as .exe.  Missing libiomp5md.dll in dist folder.
items.body:
I have a rather large python application based on a conda virtual environment.  I recently did a conda update all and ran into an issue where when I ran the application from the otherwise successfully created .exe, the application would crash when trying to create any Matplotlib plot.  The generation of these plots are requested by the user from a WxPython GUI.  Whenever a user tried to create a plot, the application would crash and immediately close both the application and the command window whether run from the command line or double click of .exe.

The application would however run on my machine but not on others.  I suspected that somehow it was running on my machine by finding a required file somewhere else outside my resulting pyinstaller dist folder.  I was able to incrementally rename folders in my conda environment to finally determine that the file "libiomp5md.dll" seems to be missing from the resulting pyinstaller distribution.  Copying a version of that file from my conda environment into the dist folder resolved the issue.

What is the recommended method to debug such issues given it was a bit fortunate that it ran at all on my machine?  I run under Windows 10 and have the following python environment.

items.title: can't build with matplotlib
items.body:
I'm trying to get a program with embedded matplotlib graphs to build as .exe on windows 10 and no matter what I try the final program always crashes without error when run independently. I am building using an anaconda environment and when I start the .exe from that environment it does not crash.

I find the same behavior for the embedded examples of wxagg and qtagg, but this is the minimal example that does not work:
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot([0,1,2], [0,1,1])
plt.show()
```

I have attached the example and the .yml file to create the anaconda environment from scratch here:
[pyinstaller_issue_matplotlib.zip](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/files/5053036/pyinstaller_issue_matplotlib.zip)

I have tried with python 3.6 and 3.7, matplotlib 3.0.x, 3.1.x, 3.2.x and pyinstaller 3.4,3.5,3.6,4.0,4.1-dev and none seem to work.
Using the --debug all options I see it crashing after import of matplotlib.pylab (or matplotlib.backend_wxagg in the embedded example).

I got this working half a year ago, but I don't know what changed with the environment. Any help to track down the issue would be appreciated. (Or an environment definition that works.)

items.title: Add check for correct names of new-fragments

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Feature request

items.body:
While releasing the last version, I was hindered by some news-fragments having the wrong filename. While this is not much of an issue, it  costs yet another few minutes to solve. But for a possible (half-)automated release pipeline, this would make some entries vanish from the change log.

The check could be part of the linting step.

Valid names are in <https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/blob/develop/doc/development/changelog-entries.rst>

draft pattern: `([^.]+)\.(feature|bugfix|…)\.rst` -> validate with towncrier

items.title: Script filename "App.py" cannot be processed by pyinstaller if a package named "App" resides in the same directory

labels.name: solution:works for me
labels.description: Resolved: Maintainers cant't reproduce or original poster made it work

labels.name: state:verify
labels.description: This needs to be verified - would be great if someone could write a test-case for

items.body:
**Bug description:** 
When your main script is called App.py, and there is a package directory called App, and you apply pyinstaller on App.py, the resulting EXE doesn't run.

**My system:**
Windows 10-64bit, Python 3.8.2, pyinstaller 4.0dev

**The minimal example to reproduce the bug:**
1) **[Edited this item]** Create file named _App.py_ with a single line in it, and create a directory _App_ with an empty \_\__init_\_\_._py_ in it:
`C:\>echo print("This should have been printed") > App.py`
`C:\>mkdir App`
`C:\>type NUL > App\__init__.py`
2) Run it with a python interpreter, and correct behavior is observed.
`C:\>python App.py`
`This should have been printed`
3) Try bundling it with pyinstaller
`C:\>pyinstaller App.py --console`
4) Run the resulting EXE and it will not print (This is the problem).
`C:\>dist\App\App.exe`
`C:\>`
5) Rename _App.py_ to _hello.py_
`C:\>copy App.py hello.py`
6) Re-run the pyinstaller
`C:\>pyinstaller hello.py --console`
7) Run the resulting EXE and it prints (no problem).
`C:\>dist\hello\hello.exe`
`This should have been printed`

items.title: Removing console (likely) affects APScheduler execution
items.body:
I used pyinstaller to bundle my programme and it has worked  great for me, so thanks for the great tool first of all! 

So the app I am freezing uses APScheduler to run several events at the same time. All the testing was done with the console activated, for debugging purposes. Now that I got it to work as it should, I removed the console window using -w or --windowed, so it is ready to be distributed to other people. In this console disabled mode, scheduling of the events is no longer correct and basically no scheduled events are being executed. Otherwise the GUI, SQL tables and all other components seem to work fine. 
I decided to log this here as a potential bug, because the programme has been thoroughly tested on various PCs and proved to work very well in console mode. On the contrary, in -w mode, the scheduling fails on two different PCs. 

Any insight into how console disabling affects pyinstaller bundling/exe performance might also help! Many thanks!

items.title: PyInstaller 4.0 is causing extra-large executables

milestone.title: PyInstaller 4.0
milestone.description:
- Remove support for Python 2.7
- Add support for moving hooks into the packages they support
- Fix a few major features

items.body:
This was first reported in #4932. After much confusion, we figured out the problem. However, I managed to replicate with `matplotlib` on Windows (#4932 was Linux-only), which caused a (onefile) executable of 1.02GB in size. When using PyInstaller 3.6, the same script (onefile) is only 27mb, or 60 when onedir.

Safe to say this blocks release 4.0.

This issue **HIGHEST PRIORITY** and takes precendence over any other issues. Please share any update as soon as you have it - even small things. 

Debugging steps:

* Find a smaller example that has a difference of ~20MB (eg tkinter) 
* `git bisect` from the `v3.6` tag

items.title: pyinstaller fails to install with pip behind a proxy

labels.name: area:install
labels.description: Installation issues.

items.body:
## Description of the issue

Pyinstaller fails to install from `pip` behind a proxy, hanging at the "build dependencies."  Even if all dependencies are installed, it still tries & fails to download build dependencies.  Even if the `--no-deps` flag is passed, it still tries & fails to download build dependencies.

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```(N/A)```
* Version of Python: 3.7
* Platform: e.g Windows 2016 (English)

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [N/A] start with clean installation
  * [N/A] use the latest development version
  * [N/A] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [N/A] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [N/A] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [N/A] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

Use a computer that has no internet access except by HTTP proxy.  `pip` & every other package works fine with that.

```
python -mpip --proxy %MYPROXYIPADDR% install pyinstaller
```

### Stacktrace / full error message

```
call C:\ProgramData\User\\Environments\venv\Scripts\activate && python -mpip --proxy %MYPROXYIPADDR% install --no-deps pyinstaller
Collecting pyinstaller
  Using cached PyInstaller-3.6.tar.gz (3.5 MB)
  Installing build dependencies ... error
  ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1:
   command: 'C:\ProgramData\User\Environments\venv\Scripts\python.exe' 'C:\ProgramData\User\Environments\venv\lib\site-packages\pip' install --ignore-installed --no-user --prefix 'C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-6dwtf8ii\overlay' --no-warn-script-location --no-binary :none: --only-binary :none: -i https://pypi.org/simple -- 'setuptools>=40.8.0' wheel
       cwd: None
  Complete output (7 lines):
  WARNING: Retrying (Retry(total=4, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ConnectTimeoutError(<pip._vendor.urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x0000024712EEDB08>, 'Connection to pypi.org timed out. (connect timeout=15)')': /simple/setuptools/
  WARNING: Retrying (Retry(total=3, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ConnectTimeoutError(<pip._vendor.urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x0000024712EEDC08>, 'Connection to pypi.org timed out. (connect timeout=15)')': /simple/setuptools/
  WARNING: Retrying (Retry(total=2, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ConnectTimeoutError(<pip._vendor.urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x0000024712EFA308>, 'Connection to pypi.org timed out. (connect timeout=15)')': /simple/setuptools/
  WARNING: Retrying (Retry(total=1, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ConnectTimeoutError(<pip._vendor.urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x0000024712EF5F48>, 'Connection to pypi.org timed out. (connect timeout=15)')': /simple/setuptools/
  WARNING: Retrying (Retry(total=0, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ConnectTimeoutError(<pip._vendor.urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x0000024712EF5DC8>, 'Connection to pypi.org timed out. (connect timeout=15)')': /simple/setuptools/
  ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement setuptools>=40.8.0 (from versions: none)
  ERROR: No matching distribution found for setuptools>=40.8.0
  ----------------------------------------
ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1: 'C:\ProgramData\User\Environments\venv\Scripts\python.exe' 'C:\ProgramData\User\Environments\venv\lib\site-packages\pip' install --ignore-installed --no-user --prefix 'C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-build-env-6dwtf8ii\overlay' --no-warn-script-location --no-binary :none: --only-binary :none: -i https://pypi.org/simple -- 'setuptools>=40.8.0' wheel Check the logs for full command output.
```

Note that compatible versions of `setuptools` and `wheel` are both already installed.  Pyinstaller fails to use pip's proxy, and shouldn't even be installing dependencies in the first place.

items.title: Issue pulling numpy.cov
items.body:
+++ ONLY TEXT +++ DO NOT POST IMAGES +++

## Description of the issue
When freezing code containing np.cov, program will build but will crash with no error when running the .exe

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6```

* Version of Python: e.g. 3.7.3

* Platform: e.g GNU/Linux (distribution), Windows (language settings), OS X, conda, FreeBSD
Windows using an anaconda virtual environment

* Did you also try this on another platform? Does it work there?
Not tested on alternative platform


### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [x] start with clean installation
  * [ ] use the latest development version
  * [x] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [x] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [x] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [x] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

```
`if __name__ == '__main__':
    ph = np.zeros((10, 100))
    print('Test numpy with zeros')
    cov = np.cov(ph)
    print('Covariance output')`
```

Program was built with:

```pyinstaller test.py --onefile```

### Stacktrace / full error message

```
No error given
```

## Description of the issue
PyTest plugin are not loaded once packed with PyInstaller

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6```
* Version of Python:  3.6.3
* Platform: Windows 10 Home, using Anaconda env

Didn't work on Mac using virtualenv.


* try the latest development version, using the following command:

```shell
pip install https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/archive/develop.zip
```

* follow *all* the instructions in our "If Things Go Wrong" Guide
  (https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/If-Things-Go-Wrong) and

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [x ] start with clean installation
  * [ x] use the latest development version
  * [ x] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [ x] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [ x] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [ x] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

```
# create venv and install pytest, pytest-html.
# activate venv and generate exe by using: 
# pyinstaller --onefile --noconfirm --nowindow --exclude-module PyQt5 --add-data "poc.py;." poc.py 

import os
import sys
import pytest
import pytest_html

def test_helloworld():
    assert True

def resource_path(relative):
    """
    pyinstaller unpacks data into a temporary folder, 
    and stores this directory path in the _MEIPASS environment variable.
    
    relative - name of the resource
    """
    try:
        if getattr(sys, 'frozen') and hasattr(sys, '_MEIPASS'):
            return os.path.join(sys._MEIPASS, relative)
    except:
        return os.path.join(os.path.abspath("."), relative)

pytest.main(["-vvv", "-p", "pytest_html", "--html=report.html", resource_path(__file__)])
```

### Stacktrace / full error message

```
ERROR: usage: poc.exe [options] [file_or_dir] [file_or_dir] [...]
poc.exe: error: unrecognized arguments: --html=report.html
  inifile: None
  rootdir: \\Mac\Home\dev\aidoc-probe
```

Please also see <https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs>
for more about what would use to solve the issue.

```
class TestThread(Thread):
    def __init__(self):
        Thread.__init__(self)
        Thread.daemon = True

    def loop_test(self):

            self.record.update_record('outcome', 'FAIL')
```

items.title: botocore adds 45MB to the package
items.body:
I'm PyInstaller to freeze my application and noticed that once `boto3` was added the size was increased dramatically.
After examining the content it looks like `botocore` is to blame, it adds 45MB of data.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7085494/87914810-ee888780-ca79-11ea-8871-80f953e1508e.png)

looking in the dir it includes multiple `json` files that take all this disk space, is this really needed? can we reduce the size somehow?

I'm willing to work on the hook if anyone can give a direction on how to handle it.

items.title: Matplotlib - NameError: name 'defaultParams' is not defined
items.body:
## Description of the issue
pyInstaller succesfully compiles the simple Matplotlib 2D graph example, and even copies over the "mpl-data" folder.
However, the exe fails to run. It complains about the defaultParams list, which is use by __init__.py of Matplotlib.
Note: Strangely the application tries to invoke files located in my miniconda3 installation folder...?

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6```
* Version of Python: 3.7.6 (Miniconda3 4.8.3) (Matplotlib 3.3.0)
* Platform: e.g Windows (english)
* Did you also try this on another platform? NO

  * [x] start with clean installation
  * [x] use the latest development version
  * [x] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [x] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [x] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [x] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.

### A minimal example program which shows the error
import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

t = np.arange(0.0, 2.0, 0.01)
s = 1 + np.sin(2 * np.pi * t)

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(t, s)

ax.set(xlabel='time (s)', ylabel='voltage (mV)',
       title='About as simple as it gets, folks')
ax.grid()

fig.savefig("test.png")
plt.show()

### Stacktrace / full error message

items.title: Add test-cases for expected output on exit

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Feature request

items.body:
Quoting from https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/pull/4907#issue-425770243
> The error was that SystemExit - the standard script exit exception, raised by sys.exit and other exit functions, was handled as a normal exception, and the bootloader printed Failed to execute script X, before erroring.

Would be a good idea to have test-cases tsting teh expected behaviour. Cases which come to my mind are:
- `sys.exit(0)`, `sys.exit(1)`
- `raise SystemExit(0)`, `raise SystemExit(1)`
- `raise ValueError` (or any other exception that suites - actually covered by `test_option_w_ignore` which raises an AssertionError)
- … more?

@Legorooj Do you want to take care of this, as you already have been working in this area.
You could use `test_option_w_ignore` as an example. If the exe return-code is non-zero, `pytest.fail()` is called (see `PyInstaller/utils/conftest.py::_test_executables()`), so for these cases you need to something like `with pytest.raises(pytest.fail) as rc:`.

```
import pandas as pd

print(abs(1))
```

items.title: compiled exe keeps coming back to the user input part
items.body:
Hi,

I did compiled my script using pyinstaller, but when I double click it, it keeps coming back to the str(input part...
I'm using multiprocessing

But it's working fine on double clicking the py script.

I was successful in my other script but this one, no luck... I've tried to comment  out all user inputs but still the same.

Can you help me figure out please?

Thanks

items.title: Error python37.dll module not found

labels.name: state:stale by author
labels.description: About to be colosed due to inactivity

items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
3. When making a bug report, make sure you provide all required information. The easier it is for
   maintainers to reproduce, the faster it'll be fixed.
-->

+++ ONLY TEXT +++ DO NOT POST IMAGES +++

## Description of the issue
I am using pyinstaller to create an .exe that should be working without any dependencies, therefore i use the -F option. Unfortunately, when I try to run this .exe in an environment that doesn't have python installed, I get 2 error popup windows:
1st: api-ms-win-crt-runtime-l1-1-0.dll is missing 
2nd: python37.dll module not found

For some weird reason the same thing happens when i use the -D option. Even though there is a python37.dll in the folder of the .exe it still says that the module was not found. 

Of course this problem leads to my program not working as a standalone application without any dependencies.

I think that this error obviously has nothing to do with my code, but rather with some settings/bugs within Pycharm/pyinstaller

Thanks in advance for any help!

UPDATE: I used the pyi-archive_viewer to check what is wrong and found only a couple of archives ... not including any of the api-ms-win-crt-*.dll and not the python37.dll. Checking out a working .exe that was compiled using pyinstaller with the pyi-archive_viewer I realised that all of these files are included in that .exe file. Does anybody happen to know the root of this issue?

Here is my archive-table:
```
 pos, length, uncompressed, iscompressed, type, name
[(0, 282, 369, 1, 'm', 'struct'),
 (282, 1132, 1850, 1, 'm', 'pyimod01_os_path'),
 (1414, 4033, 8634, 1, 'm', 'pyimod02_archive'),
 (5447, 5350, 12464, 1, 'm', 'pyimod03_importers'),
 (10797, 1820, 4098, 1, 's', 'pyiboot01_bootstrap'),
 (12617, 320, 438, 1, 's', 'pyi_rth__tkinter'),
 (12937, 1984, 3396, 1, 's', 'pictureValidation'),
 (14921, 1263248, 1263248, 0, 'z', 'PYZ-00.pyz')]
```
As you can see there is not a single entry of the type 'b', which seems to be the type that is missing as all of the missing files are type 'b' as seen in another working .exe:

items.title: Ignore imports behind `if __name__ == "__main__"` in standard library
items.body:
## Description of the issue

Some standard library modules import unrelated things behind `if __name__ == "__main__"` tests, like [heapq.py](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.8/Lib/heapq.py#L600), which imports `doctest` for unit testing.

This sucks in an enormous number of dependencies, including even `ctypes` as of 3.8 due to a long chain of includes.

A frozen app will never run standard library files as `__main__`, so it would make sense for pyinstaller (or perhaps at the modulegraph level?) to ignore these.  It will also shrink the size of small compiled executables by a fair margin.

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: all, through ```4.0.dev0```
* Version of Python: All, through 3.10 (dev)
* Platform: All

items.title: --runtime-tmpdir behavior strange - enhancement wish: extract only once to speed up --onefile

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Feature request

items.body:
Update: I found out many stuff by myself, so you might skip A and directly jump to B.

A)

First of all, seems to be the best way to create an exe from a py, thanks a lot!

I created both, an onedir and an onefile variant. For a console application just doing something with sys.argv parameter..

I understand that the onefile variant needs to unpack first. In the documentation you say you could specify a --runtime-tmpdir .. however it seems not to work for me on Windows, or I am doing it wrong?

Plus, I miss this information: will it unpack every time, or only the first time? Many people complain about the slow startup time for the --onefile variant. So why not unpack only once, and for the second start just check if it was already unpacked and then skip this unpacking process. Is this already done, or not?

Another thing is that I have to exclude a lot of stuff, which I even do not use in my console application. Even in a very fresh venv without any modules installed there.

```
(venv) C:\workspace\python\handler>pyinstaller extractor.py --exclude asyncio --exclude socket --exclude bz2 --exclude hashlib --exclude lzma --exclude ssl --exclude select --exclude unicodedata --exclude pyexpat --onefile --runtime-tmpdir c:\workspace\python\handler\dist\tmp
```

As you see I pass it like this: ```--runtime-tmpdir c:\workspace\python\handler\dist\tmp```
I also tried to pass the path with normal slash /, but still, nothing in tmp folder after executing the one-file-exe.
I even created the tmp folder before, but did not help. No files.

B)

It would be quite bad if it's just unpacked, executed and deleted afterwards, then this option would not speed up things, which is wished by so many users, see e.g.:
https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/issues/1782
https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/issues/4980

This might be related to:
https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/pull/4720

Update: I added ```print(f"The app is running in directory {sys._MEIPASS}")``` in the py file and get as output for 2 runs:

```
The app is running in directory c:\workspace\python\handler\dist\tmp\_MEI27162
The app is running in directory c:\workspace\python\handler\dist\tmp\_MEI74042
```

So I fear it's unpacked, but deleted after execution. So I might add the enhancement wish: why we can't extract in one specific folder, and just only once? It would speed up --onefile so much and make so many users happy ;-)

Later I added something to pause the app.. and now I see it's really unpacking the files there, but after execution deleting it.

Okay, I see the name tmpdir might include this meaning. So, what about a new option --runtime-permanent-unpackdir or something like that. BTW, I don't see how I could change the label, but you might change it to feature request.

Else:

It is your problem to solve.

Pyinstaller is meant to help people freeze their apps, not some must-aquire-fully knowledge for each app-programmer. Just like a car driver who drives to pick up his kids shouldn't have to know how his V12 Turbo Engine is designed, tested and built. items.title: .app CRUSHES ALL THE TIME with a solution I have no idea what is going on
items.body:
@ScarlettCharlie that document will tell you exactly what is wrong: You're not accessing the files correctly. You need to use a snippet of code like this:

```python
from os import path
import sys
bundle_dir = getattr(sys, '_MEIPASS', path.abspath(path.dirname(__file__)))
path_to_dat = path.abspath(path.join(bundle_dir, 'other-file.dat'))
```

_Originally posted by @Legorooj in https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/issues/4977#issuecomment-656596243_

Yes, but that's it? Huh??

items.title: No Module Named 'xxx'.
items.body:
OS : macOS Catalina
I pip-installed pyinstaller to pack my app in which one of my .py file has imported xxx
Like this:
import xxx
from xxx import ...

I followed all the steps, opened the app from the terminal and it always says
No Module Named 'xxx'

my main python file is in the first layer of my Sources, while other python files I programmed is underneath it.
and here's my .spec file:
# -*- mode: python ; coding: utf-8 -*-

block_cipher = None
a = Analysis(['1.py','],
             pathex=['/something/myApp'],
             binaries=[],
             datas=[],
             hiddenimports=['xxx'],
<and everything else...>

and xxx in installed in the same environment where I installed pyinstaller(I used pip3 install pyinstaller command)

-------------------------- How it is solved--------------------------

When packaging my app again, I didn't use pyinstaller -Fw myapp.py

instead, to let pyinstaller know where my packages are, I used this
pyinstaller -p the_package_path_pyinstaller_didn't_recogize_before -Fw myapp.py

HOWEVER

New issues showed up, see comments.

items.title: PyInstaller can't detect uses of `importlib`, `imp`, or any method that doesn't use the standard `from ... import ...` or `import ...` syntax.

labels.name: state:stale by author
labels.description: About to be colosed due to inactivity

items.body:
PyInstaller can't detect uses of `importlib`, `imp`, or any method that doesn't use the standard `from ... import ...` or `import ...` syntax.

Please use the `--hidden-import` option to specify extra imports to include, and the `-p PATH` to specify extra python paths.

_Originally posted by @Legorooj in https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/issues/4973#issuecomment-653991044_

Sounds good. What's the difference between --hidden-import and --additional-hooks-dir in this case? Also, I tried adding  --hidden-import "scripts.*" but didn't see to pick up anything - so how should this look? 

Actually, if I may ask as well, is it possible to mix the environments? Like if I was able to get python install it starts using that python install as well? I still want the main program as the exe - but I could install python at will if its just a matter of missing modules.

items.title: productVersionLS and fileVersionLS: 2279604224 (0x87e00000) only in Azure DevOps CI causes  struct.error: argument out of range.
items.body:
## Description of the issue We have been using pyinstaller v3.6 for months without isssues in CI, suddenly without any code changes CI broke with `struct.error: argument out of range`. I tried: - `4.0.dev0+g7a7eb11a` --> `7a7eb11a * develop origin/develop` with python 3.8, that works but later on I saw issue #4311, therefore maybe not a good idea. - `4.0.dev0+g7a7eb11a` --> with python 3.7, ok. ## Context information (for bug reports) * Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6``` * Version of Python: 3.7 * Platform: e.g GNU/Linux (distribution), Windows ### Stacktrace / full error message I added som prints to see what's going on. Since my .spec file works locally but suddenly broke in CI.
Stacktrace (CLICK ME)

``` 39984 INFO: Writing RT_GROUP_ICON 0 resource with 20 bytes 39984 INFO: Writing RT_ICON 1 resource with 7450 bytes Traceback (most recent call last): struct.pack('L12l', 4277077181, 65536, 131078, 2279604224, 131078, 2279604224, 63, 0, 262148, 1, 0, 0, 0) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main "__main__", mod_spec) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code exec(code, run_globals) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\__main__.py", line 121, in run() File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\__main__.py", line 114, in run run_build(pyi_config, spec_file, **vars(args)) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\__main__.py", line 65, in run_build PyInstaller.building.build_main.main(pyi_config, spec_file, **kwargs) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\building\build_main.py", line 734, in main build(specfile, kw.get('distpath'), kw.get('workpath'), kw.get('clean_build')) File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\building\build_main.py", line 681, in build ##[error]Cmd.exe exited with code '1'. exec(code, spec_namespace) rawffi = self.ffi.toRaw() File "C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\Python\3.7.7\x64\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\utils\win32\versioninfo.py", line 320, in toRaw self.fileDateLS) struct.error: argument out of range ```

Same Print local vs CI ``` struct.pack('L12l', self.sig, self.strucVersion, self.fileVersionMS, self.fileVersionLS, self.productVersionMS, self.productVersionLS, self.fileFlagsMask, self.fileFlags, self.fileOS, self.fileType, self.fileSubtype, self.fileDateMS, self.fileDateLS) locally: struct.pack('L12l', 4277077181, 65536, 131077, 0, 131077, 0, 63, 0, 262148, 1, 0, 0, 0) CI: struct.pack('L12l', 4277077181, 65536, 131078, 2279604224, 131078, 2279604224, 63, 0, 262148, 1, 0, 0, 0) ``` self.fileVersionLS: 2279604224 (0x87e00000) self.productVersionLS: 2279604224 (0x87e00000) How important are `fileVersionLS` and `productVersionLS`. As a workaround I am thinking of hardcoding them to zero on a fork until the next version of pyinstaller comes out, pyinstaller @develop + python 3.8 seems to work even though work is still to be done with the bootloader. Suggestions? **Update**: python3.7 and latest develop works.

items.title: pyqt5-based app build on Centos 7 fail to run on Ubuntu 18.04 or recent Fedora
items.body:
## Description of the issue

A simple hello-world pyqt5 app build on CentOS 7 fails with SIGBART on Fedora 31 and 32 and on Ubuntu 18.04:

Fedora 32 running Wayland:
```
./hi 
Warning: Ignoring XDG_SESSION_TYPE=wayland on Gnome. Use QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland to run on Wayland anyway.
qt.qpa.plugin: Could not load the Qt platform plugin "xcb" in "" even though it was found.
This application failed to start because no Qt platform plugin could be initialized. Reinstalling the application may fix this problem.

Available platform plugins are: eglfs, linuxfb, minimal, minimalegl, offscreen, vnc, wayland-egl, wayland, wayland-xcomposite-egl, wayland-xcomposite-glx, webgl, xcb.

fish: “./hi” terminated by signal SIGABRT (Abort)
```
(note noise about Wayland in there: changes QT_QPA_PLATFORM does not help).

Ubuntu 18.04 running X:
```

```

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6```
* Version of Python: 3.6
* Platform: building on GNU/Linux CentOS 7, running on Fedora 31, 32 or Ubuntu 18.04.
* Did you also try this on another platform?  It works building on Ubuntu 19.10 w/ Python 3.7, running on Fedora 32.

* try the latest development version: yes, same behaviour

* follow *all* the instructions in our "If Things Go Wrong" Guide
  (https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/If-Things-Go-Wrong) and

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [x] start with clean installation  (Tested on new `centos:7` docker image)
  * [x] use the latest development version
  * [x] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [x] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [x] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [x] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

`hi.py` with following content:
```
from PyQt5.QtWidgets import *
app = QApplication([])
label = QLabel('Hello World!')
label.show()
app.exec_()
```

items.title: PyInstaller DLL load failed: pywrap_tensorflow_internal Tensorflow 2.2
items.body:
Tensorflow 2.2 doesn't work with Pyinstaller. I have Pyinstaller 4.0-dev and Tensorflow 2.2.0, and I keep getting the error: 
ImportError: No module named '_pywrap_tensorflow_internal'.
ImportError:DLL load failed: The specified module could not be found.

Failed to load the native Tensorflow runtime.

items.title: Pyinstaller can not freeze SVD functions
items.body:
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
3. When making a bug report, make sure you provide all required information. The easier it is for
   maintainers to reproduce, the faster it'll be fixed.
-->

## Description of the issue
I have been trying to freeze a python script that contains an instance of an SVD function (single value decomposition) without success. Everytime the executable runs it, it crashes the program without any error message or exception that I can catch (nor any message appears with the --debug option of pyinstaller). However, when I remove this function of the code, everything works fine.

What is the most surprising of this problem, is that the executable works fine if I run it through the conda prompt. But fails if it is run by double-clicking it. Adding all the missing .dll dependancies that the build log mentions does not fix this issue.

I isolated the problem using a minimal script containing only the SVD. I tried three homologous functions from OpenCV (4.3.0), Numpy (1.18.5) and Scipy (1.5.0), and all three fail (although the OpenCV version seems to work sometimes). 

Thanks for your support, and I hope this issue might just be something trivial.

I'm using:
* Pyinstaller Version: 3.6
* Version of Python: 3.7.7
* Platform: Windows (English), Anaconda3

### A minimal example program which shows the error

```
import numpy as np
import cv2
import scipy.linalg as scilin

np.random.seed(42)
a = np.random.random((15,20))

w = np.zeros(a.shape[0]); u = np.zeros((a.shape[0], a.shape[0])); vt = np.zeros(a.shape)
cv2.SVDecomp(a, w, u, vt)
print(w.shape, u.shape, vt.shape)

u2,w2,vt2 = np.linalg.svd(a, full_matrices=False, compute_uv=True)
print(w2.shape, u2.shape, vt2.shape)

u3,w3,vt3 = scilin.svd(a, full_matrices=False, compute_uv=True)
print(w3.shape, u3.shape, vt3.shape)
```

items.title: Html test Runner Reports Not Generated If running with  exe
items.body:
Please use the mailing list see <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list> for details.

Posts that are not a bug report or a feature/enhancement request will not be addressed on this issue tracker, but closed.
Hello guys Kindly help me , i have generated a exe file which implements some unit-test cases & report is generated in html the script runs as expected when running via console but when i have created exe usin Pyinstaller script runs fine upto unittest cases execution but i get error at html report generation i am confused how to fix this     error --IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: ] No such file or directory: 'C:\\Users\\pc1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\_MEI24~1\\HtmlTestRunner\\template\\report_template.html'


    """
    import os
    import sys
    import time
    import unittest
    
    import HtmlTestRunner
    
    
    
    class Test_J(unittest.TestCase):
    
        def test_Key1(self):
            
            pass
    
        def test_Key2(self):
            pass
    
    
    
           
          
    
        def test_Key3r(self):
    
            pass
    
      
    if __name__ == '__main__':
    
        try:
            output1 = 'D:\\Reports'
            title1 = ' Testing Ver-1.0'
            name1 = ' Testing '
    
            unittest.main(testRunner=HtmlTestRunner.HTMLTestRunner(output=output1, report_title=title1,
                                                                   report_name=name1), exit=False,
                          verbosity=2)
    
      
            
        else:
    
            print("Thank You Tests Are Finished - Report Generated  )
    
          
            raw_input("Press Enter To Exit")

Hi I've tried to implement a hook using examples in other threads but still running in to the same error message

This is the library is the cause of it all
`from tendo import singleton`

This is the error message I always received (before using hooks and after)
pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: The 'tendo' distribution was not found and is required by the application

Created a hook and hook directory
```
myscript.py
hooks
     - hook-tendo.py (also tried hook-tendo.singleton.py)
```

My hook file is 
```
from PyInstaller.utils.hooks import collect_all

datas, binaries, hiddenimports = collect_all('tendo')
```
have also tried collect_all('tendo.singleton')

pyinstaller --F --noupx --nowindowed --additional-hooks-dir=hooks myscript.py

items.title: Rename executable after it was build
items.body:
I'm using PyInstaller to build my application for Windows, Linux & Mac.
I'm packing the application as `onedir` and not `onefile`.

I need to be able to make a copy of the executable with a different name before running it, on Linux & Mac there is no issue but doing so on windows, I'm getting "Runtime Error!"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7085494/86168445-e1cede80-bb20-11ea-80bd-3d0e9973cec5.png)

I understand that there is a `.manifest` file that is needed so I copied it to with the new name and still getting the same error.
Also changing the `name` in the `assemblyIdentity` tag didn't help.

Is there a way to achieve this on Windows?

items.title: Subprocess exits when opening .app file, not when opening executable
items.body:
I'm having a weird problem which I'm having a hard time to debug. So I'm trying to build our software [Tribler](https://github.com/tribler/tribler), and I'm running into an issue on Mac, using Python 3.8 and the 4.0 develop version of Pyinstaller. Our application uses PyQt5 to show a GUI, and that GUI spawns a subprocess using `QProcess` (the code can be found [here](https://github.com/Tribler/tribler/blob/release-7.5/src/tribler-gui/tribler_gui/core_manager.py#L82)). The `.app` file builds fine and it starts by showing the GUI. However, the subprocess immediately exists with status code 1. When running the executable from the command line (e.g., `cd /Applications/Tribler.app/Contents/MacOS/ && ./tribler`), the subprocess does not exist and Tribler runs fine!

I reverted the commit that introduced `QProcess` to use `multiprocessing` again, and then it seems to work properly. I will try to make a minimal example to pin-point this behaviour, but I've created this issue in the hope that someone has encountered the same.

[The .spec file we are using](https://github.com/Tribler/tribler/blob/release-7.5/tribler.spec)

print(requests_toolbelt)

items.title: Successful building but Python37.dll error on running .exe

labels.name: state:need info
labels.description: Need more information for solve or help.

items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
3. When making a bug report, make sure you provide all required information. The easier it is for
   maintainers to reproduce, the faster it'll be fixed.
-->

+++ ONLY TEXT +++ DO NOT POST IMAGES +++

## Description of the issue

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: ```(paste here)```
* Version of Python: e.g. 3.7
* Platform: e.g GNU/Linux (distribution), Windows (language settings), OS X, conda, FreeBSD
* Did you also try this on another platform? Does it work there?


* try the latest development version, using the following command: 

```shell
pip install https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/archive/develop.zip
```

* follow *all* the instructions in our "If Things Go Wrong" Guide
  (https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/If-Things-Go-Wrong) and

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [ ] start with clean installation
  * [ ] use the latest development version
  * [ ] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [ ] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [ ] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [ ] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.


### A minimal example program which shows the error

```
a.spec
```
```
I used python setup.py install to install pyinstaller
`
# -*- mode: python ; coding: utf-8 -*-

block_cipher = None


a = Analysis(['src/mailer/__main__.py'],
             pathex=[],
             binaries=[],
             datas=[("src/index.png", ".")],
             hiddenimports=[],
             hookspath=[],
             runtime_hooks=[],
             excludes=['pyinstaller'],
             win_no_prefer_redirects=False,
             win_private_assemblies=False,
             cipher=block_cipher,
             noarchive=False)
pyz = PYZ(a.pure, a.zipped_data,
             cipher=block_cipher)
exe = EXE(pyz,
          a.scripts,
          [],
          exclude_binaries=False,
          name='Mailer',
          debug=True,
          bootloader_ignore_signals=False,
          strip=False,
          upx=True,
          console=False , icon='./src/mailer.ico')
coll = COLLECT(exe,
               a.binaries,
               a.zipfiles,
               a.datas,
               strip=False,
               upx=True,
               upx_exclude=[],
               name='Mailer')
`
```
Well, I can post an image of project directory.
When I run mailer.exe by going into `dist`
I check too many popup dialogs which I close by terminating process through task manager.

Header of popup box says `Tracing...`

[1348] Pyinstaller Bootloader 3.x

10 more messages(too much to type for me)

and at the end

Error loading Python DLL
C:\Users\Dell\AppData\Local\Temp\_MEI140002\python37.dll
LoadLibrary:The specified module could not be found


I tried setting debug=True in a.spec and even setting exclude_binaries with both True /False, console True/False but nothing worked after wasting 3+ hours.
```

“Minimal“ means: remove everything from your code which is not relevant for this bug,
esp. don't use external programs, remote requests, etc.
A very good example is https://gist.github.com/ronen/024cdae9ff2d50488438. This one helped
us reproducing and fixing a quite complex problem within approx 1 hour.
```

items.title: data file not found when using --add-data with --onefile
items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
3. When making a bug report, make sure you provide all required information. The easier it is for
   maintainers to reproduce, the faster it'll be fixed.
-->

+++ ONLY TEXT +++ DO NOT POST IMAGES +++

## Description of the issue
I'm trying to contribute to this project: https://github.com/akmalhakimi1991/mousemover

As the first step, I'm trying to rebuild the project, which was successfully built with PyInstaller previously. After cloning the source to c:\myprojects\mousemover using Sourcetree, I created the virtual environment using the command

    pip -m venv venv

Next, I install the dependency with command 

    pip install -r requirements.txt

Then cd into mousemover folder, and type 

    python mousemover.py

And the program runs correctly. Now building the exe by using the command

    pyinstaller --onefile --add-data "config.yml;." mousemover.py

The executable mousemover.exe is created in folder dist. If I type the command

    dist\mousemover.exe

it works because the exe is reading the config.yml inside the source folder. But if I cd into dist, then type mousemover.exe, the error message is:

    (venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover\mousemover\dist>mousemover.exe
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "mousemover\mousemover.py", line 27, in <module>
    FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'config.yml'
    [11200] Failed to execute script mousemover

The file mousemover.spec have the entry 

    datas=[('config.yml', '.')],

under the Analysis class.

I have searched the Internet and looks at several answers in StackOverflow, but none have worked so far. Maybe I'm still not familiar with the whole PyInstaller feature

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: 
(venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover>pyinstaller --version
3.6

* Version of Python: e.g. 3.7
(venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover>python --version
Python 3.7.7

* Platform: e.g GNU/Linux (distribution), Windows (language settings), OS X, conda, FreeBSD
(venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover>systeminfo

OS Name:                   Microsoft Windows 10 Home Single Language
OS Version:                10.0.18363 N/A Build 18363

* Did you also try this on another platform? Does it work there?
No other platform to test

* try the latest development version, using the following command:

```shell
pip install https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/archive/develop.zip
```

same error message:
(venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover\mousemover\dist>mousemover.exe
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mousemover.py", line 27, in <module>
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'config.yml'
[12076] Failed to execute script mousemover

(venv) C:\myprojects\mousemover\mousemover\dist>pyinstaller --version
4.0.dev0

* follow *all* the instructions in our "If Things Go Wrong" Guide
  (https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/If-Things-Go-Wrong) and

### Make sure [everything is packaged correctly](https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/How-to-Report-Bugs#make-sure-everything-is-packaged-correctly)

  * [ ] start with clean installation
  * [ ] use the latest development version
  * [ ] Run your frozen program **from a command window (shell)** — instead of double-clicking on it
  * [ ] Package your program in **--onedir mode**
  * [ ] Package **without UPX**, say: use the option `--noupx` or set `upx=False` in your .spec-file
  * [ ] Repackage you application in **verbose/debug mode**. For this, pass the option `--debug` to `pyi-makespec` or `pyinstaller` or use `EXE(..., debug=1, ...)` in your .spec file.

* Using --onedir worked because the file config.yml is inside the directory
* Using the command pyi-archive_viewer PKG-00.pkg can see the file in the archive
* Trying to add --debug all but it failed. Command:
pyinstaller --debug all --clean --onefile --add-data "config.yml;." mousemover.py

Error message:
--snip earlier lines--
5585 INFO: Including run-time hook 'c:\\myprojects\\mousemover\\venv\\lib\\site-packages\\PyInstaller\\hooks\\rthooks\\pyi_rth_pyqt5.py'
5591 INFO: Looking for dynamic libraries

    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "C:\Users\sharuzzaman\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "C:\myprojects\mousemover\venv\Scripts\pyinstaller.exe\__main__.py", line 9, in <module>
  File "c:\myprojects\mousemover\venv\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\__main__.py", line 114, in run
    run_build(pyi_config, spec_file, **vars(args))
  File "c:\myprojects\mousemover\venv\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\__main__.py", line 65, in run_build
    PyInstaller.building.build_main.main(pyi_config, spec_file, **kwargs)
  File "c:\myprojects\mousemover\venv\lib\site-packages\PyInstaller\building\build_main.py", line 716, in main

items.title: PyInstaller icon option doesn't work on Mac
items.body:
I ran the following command on my mac and created an .app file.

`pyinstaller --icon icon.icns --noconsole -n testApp main.py
`

However, the generated .app file does not show the icon.
icon.icns is specified as an icon file in info.plist.
The Content/Resouces folder contains icon.icns.

When I run the .app file, I see an icon on the Dock.

However, the icon is not reflected in the .app file itself. Why is this?
On Windows, when the .exe file was output by pyinstaller, the icon was reflected without problems.

I posted the same question on [StackOverflow ](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/62451711/pyinstaller-icon-option-doesnt-work-on-mac)with images.

items.title: Pyinstaller with UPX causes a VCRUNTIME140.dll malfunction
items.body:
## Description of the issue
I copied upx.exe under Python38 folder and then run pyinstaller to build exe file for my project with command pyinstaller -i ./pic/Logo.ico --version-file file_version_info.txt --uac-admin APCStart.py, then I run the exe file in ./dist/APCStart/. After that the computer shows me an error that tells me vcruntime140.dll does not work properly. After I replace the vcruntime140.dll with the one under Python38 folder, the program works properly. My UPX version is upx-3.96-win64. I tried upx-3.96-win32, and had a same result.

## Context information (for bug reports)

* Output of `pyinstaller --version`: 3.6
* Version of Python: 3.8.3
* Platform: Windows 10 Pro
* Did you also try this on another platform? Does it work there?
No, I only test on Windows 10 Pro

items.title: Recursive process spawn with asyncio\aiohttp
items.body:
## Description of the issue

When I'm running script with `python script.py` command, recieving expected behavior. Running bundled `script.exe` file causes infinite process spawn (IMHO fork but I haven't verified that).

External dependency: `aiohttp==3.6.2`

## Context information (for bug reports)

* `pyinstaller --version`: ```3.6```
* `python --version`: ```Python 3.7.3```
* Platform: Windows (Russian)
* Did you also try this on another platform? Does it work there? - Haven't tried.

### A minimal example program which shows the error

```python
import asyncio
import multiprocessing as mp

import aiohttp


async def main():
    async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
        async with session.ws_connect('wss://ws.bitstamp.net/') as ws:
            async for msg in ws:
                pass

    
class WebSocketProcess(mp.Process):
    def run(self):
        loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
        loop.create_task(main())
        loop.run_forever()
        loop.close()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    WebSocketProcess(daemon=True).start()
    while True:
        pass
```

labels.name: state:stale by author
labels.description: About to be colosed due to inactivity

items.body:
## Environment and related versions
Ubuntu 18.04
python 3.6.5
pyinstaller 3.5
mmcv 
mmdetection 1.2
yapf 0.30.0

## Main problem
```
"No module named yapf" is reported during program execution
```

## Related attempts
First of all, this module is determined to exist, and can be used normally in pycharm.
```
Name: yapf
Version: 0.30.0
Summary: A formatter for Python code.
Home-page: UNKNOWN
Author: Google Inc.
Author-email: None
License: Apache License, Version 2.0
Location: /home/jc/anaconda3/envs/tf-gpu/lib/python3.6/site-packages
Requires: 
Required-by: mmcv
```

I know that --hidden-import can import modules, so I modified the spec file：
```
hiddenimports=['addict','yapf'],
```
But it has no effect.

 Error reporting when compiling with spec file“ Error:can not find hidden import yapf” 

I find the path of yapf in the virtual environment and index it with - P. the compilation instructions are as follows：
```
pyinstaller my.spec -p=the_dir_of_yapf
```
 But it still doesn't work .

Is there any solution? thank you very much！

items.title: Add a hook for pygraphviz

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Feature request

items.body:
<!--
Welcome to the PyInstaller issue tracker! Before creating an issue, please heed the following:

1. This tracker should only be used to report bugs and request features / enhancements to PyInstaller
    - For questions and general support, use the mailing list, see
	  <http://www.pyinstaller.org/support.html#mailing-list>
2. Use the search function before creating a new issue. Duplicates will be closed and directed to
   the original discussion.
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
There does not seem to be support for pygraphviz. The graphviz-related functions for networkx are also effected by this.  The following simple program is not properly bundled, for example.

```
import pygraphviz as pgv

G = pgv.AGraph()
G.add_edge('a', 'b')

G.draw('xdotout.xdot', format='xdot', prog='dot')
```

After packaging with `pyinstaller --noconfirm --windowed --onedir pygraphviztest.py` we get:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1321, in _get_prog
  File "pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1569, in _which
ValueError: No prog dot in path.

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "pygraphviztest.py", line 13, in <module>
    G.draw('xdotout.xdot', format='xdot', prog='dot')
  File "pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1515, in draw
  File "pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1336, in _run_prog
  File "pygraphviz/agraph.py", line 1323, in _get_prog
ValueError: Program dot not found in path.
[41833] Failed to execute script pygraphviztest
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be nice to have a hook that properly includes all of the graphviz binaries and dynamic libraries.

**Additional context**
A hook like the following is not sufficient due to the many dependencies of graphviz.

```
binaries=[
          ('/usr/local/bin/dot', '.'),
          ('/usr/local/bin/nop', '.'),
          ('/usr/local/Cellar/graphviz/*/lib/*.dylib', '.'),
          ('/usr/local/Cellar/graphviz/*/lib/graphviz/*.dylib', 'graphviz'),
         ]

datas=[
       ('/usr/local/Cellar/graphviz/*/lib/graphviz/config6', 'graphviz'),
      ]
```

The dependencies on macOS are numerous:

```
=> brew deps graphviz
cairo
fontconfig
freetype
fribidi
gd
gdbm
gettext
glib
graphite2
gts
harfbuzz
icu4c
jasper
jpeg
libffi
libpng
libtiff
libtool
lzo
netpbm
openssl@1.1
pango
pcre
pixman
python
readline
sqlite
webp
xz
```

So I've been looking for a way to include all of the shared libraries programmatically but am not sure how to do this. I found the function `depend.bindepend.findSystemLibrary`, but did not find a function that does such a recursive crawl of dynamic library dependencies.
